Topic.Title: lordy, is BBRY still a good investment after today's 10% pop?

Message.Msg: I've been trading BBRY since October. Made loads of money. I held from 8-16.4. Ever since that I just buy on good dips and sell within a week and repeat. The news on the million phone sale today could make this hard to get back to the 14's but I'm out on this trade unless we see 14's again before earnings. You probably missed the move but the shorts have had a lot of control so maybe you will lucky and get a big pull back. What I expect to see tomorrow is for this to be up big pre-market and it will rise at the opening with the new investors coming in to buy. Around 10am there should be a big sell off and short manipulation. Not sure how low they can take it with all the news and interest. Hopefully the shorts can take at least a dollar off of the price. If the shorts can't take control back then this will go past $17 tomorrow with short covering. This gain that we had might be different than the last ones and keep going up. It's too risky to me to buy at these levels. Good luck

Topic.Title: Nobody really cares about new galaxy features

Message.Msg: Eye-scroll is a piece of technology that would show the world how far advanced Samsung’s software engineering has become. That would mark good progress by Samsung but it would not be enough. Samsung needs an innovation model that incorporates hardware, software and services. More of that in a minute. Apple finally made an appearance on the subject of the S4, yesterday. In a Reuters interview global marketing chief Phil Schiller, engaged in a small spoiler routine, saying the S4 would ship with old Android software. Maybe, maybe not. There are far better reasons for Apple to believe they now have a year to get the iPhone back into innovation mode.

Topic.Title: Nobody really cares about new galaxy features

Message.Msg: With due respect I don't thnk you're thinking from the perspective of the retail consumer. I don't choose not to buy because something is not authentic or copied off someone else. I buy because of how the product makes me feel viscerally, how successful the marketing is to make me really want it, what other tech reviewers are saying about it. I have a Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 LTE and I absolutely love it. The people I know who use iphone are waiting for the next iteration. But likewise those with the S3 are dying for the S4 to come out. The retail consumer who buys ultimately doesn't care a whit about people who are investors, and their decisions power sales and ultimately performance of the stocks we buy. I am long AAPL but I'm not going to bash Samsung just because of it.

Message.Msg: 9. Wearable Computers - The Next Paradigm Shift in Tech & Telecom Augmented Reality, AR Software, mobile AR browsers, Computer Vision, Mobile technology, Apps will create more information , data and storage solution and use 10. Hardware optimization along with increasing mobile bandwidth, academic, industrial & market research, the growth of developer & open-source communities and capital investments into the AR industry are contributing to the evolution of increasingly sophisticated AR experiences for a wide-range of devices and hands free apps. Speech recognition is yet another nascent technology set to explode with the rise of tablets and smartphones, and no company is better poised to benefit from this coming boom than Nuance Communications 11. a Microsoft Executive recently posted on Technet, he added “With 47 percent share of the current-generation console market in the U.S., we are hitting our stride largely as a result of the success of Kinect for Xbox 360 (19 million sold worldwide)”. Whereas the Xbox launched into a “safe” sector in home-entertainment, one can imagine that AR HMDs will have an always-on setting, operating both indoor and outdoor. This will raise some interesting challenges to social norms, in ethical and legal terms. They will empower users with near real-time access to in-context information, for example, the translation of a foreign language, data visualization, schematics for maintenance, gamification, or facial recognition and profiling. 12. It is likely that AR HMDs and wearables will be one of the next major tech and telecom paradigm shifts. Potential demand for the hardware could be on a par with smartphones or tablet devices and the software similarly so. Nuance is projected to grow by an average of 19% over the next two years, yet it's only valued at nine times forward earnings. Can you say "Hello, Mr. Opportunity"? 13. the prototype Project Glass device uses a 4th Generation dual-core Texas Instrumen

Message.Msg: Soros was also buying shares of Apple Inc. (AAPL), in contrast to many hedge funds; in fact, Apple lost its place as the most popular stock among hedge funds last quarter to AIG (find more of hedge funds' favorite stocks). The fall in Apple's stock price, in anticipation of an era of lower earnings, has brought the trailing earnings multiple down to 10. Market expectations are diverging wildly from analysts, whose growth expectations currently imply a five-year PEG ratio of 0.5. That is probably too rosy a prediction but it's certainly possible that Apple will manage to keep its net income about flat.

Message.Title: BTIG Apple To Miss Q2 And Q3 Slashes FY 2013 Top & Bottom Line Estimates
Message.Msg: BTIG is going against the grain and upgrading Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) from Neutral to Buy with a price target of $540 Thursday, citing many revenue opportunities which they believe can return the company to EPS growth in 2014. "We believe the stock is reflecting low buy-side investor expectations, even if the sell-side has not yet caught up with their estimate revisions," analyst Walter Piecyk said. Apple will also benefit from a reversal of the impacts of the tighter phone upgrade policies in the United States, its most important market, and is likely to come to a decision on its cash by the end of the month." Notably, BTIG downgraded Apple's stock to Neutral last April when the stock was 32.4 percent higher as $633.68. The upgrade comes despite the firm seeing an earnings miss for the upcoming March quarter and a pretty disappointing June guidance. In fact, the firm cut numbers today, and their March and June EPS estimates are now 8% and 19% below consensus, respectively. The upgrade is based in part on the firm's belief that Apple will deliver a lower-priced iPhone by the end of the year. "We believe a product that addresses the more than 70% of global wireless subscribers that are unsubsidized pre-paid is necessary in order for Apple to grow its EPS next year," the analyst said. This is not "rocket science", they said, and the company can deliver while still staying true its mantra of only making great products. The firm cut June quarter revenues to $35 billion and $7.80 of EPS on an expectation of 27.5 million phones sold compared to a consensus view north of $40 billion in revenue and $9.59 in EPS.

Message.Title: CNBC partnerships
Message.Msg: Partnerships [edit]Dow Jones & Company Since December 1997, the network has held a strategic alliance with the publishing and financial information firm Dow Jones & Company.[13] Under the agreement, CNBC has extensive access to the journalism of such outlets as MarketWatch, The Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones Newswires and Barron's, with their reporters and editorial staff making frequent appearances on the channel. Some former CNBC programs have included Dow Jones branding,[13] while the network currently produces and syndicates the weekly Wall Street Journal Report with Maria Bartiromo.[55] CNBC's current deal with Dow Jones expires in 2012, and its continuation has been the subject of some uncertainty following the 2007 acquisition of Dow by News Corporation, parent company of rival financial network Fox Business, which had been started just two months prior and whose resources have been used to build up Fox Business.[56] News Corp CEO Rupert Murdoch has stated that the current agreement "covers actual news and access to reporters on business news" only, and that Fox and Dow Jones are free to cooperate on other issues.[56] [edit] As you can see they can easily feed you any junk they want though their partnerships!!.

Even using some cash for a deal, the firm said with an estimated $144 billion in cash at the end of the March quarter there is plenty of room to increase the divined or share repurchase. Topic.Title: Todays Boutique Firm Upgrade Was To Get A Bankster Out Of The Name

Message.Msg: WSJ agrees: “What better time to upgrade the stock,” he asks. “We once again believe that investors need to take a deep breath during the rapid drop in the stock and leading into what could be a difficult quarterly to take a moment to consider the various and significant revenue and product opportunities available to the company, the lapsing of the tighter upgrade polices in the United States, its most important market, and the investment opportunities of $150 billion of cash.” The upgrade is certainly somewhat speculative: Piecyk acknowledges it’s based on the potential of “products and services that have not yet been announced and more importantly, an expectation that the management team will actually pursue them.” He expects the company will introduce a cheaper version of the iPhone, which could add $11 billion to fiscal 2014 revenue, even after accounting for some cannibalization of the higher priced models. He also put into his fiscal 2014 revenue estimate an extra $5 billion for a new product, one that hasn’t even been announced nor does he hazard a guess as to what it is. “How is that for giving the management team the benefit of the doubt that many believe has been lacking from the investment community?”

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Soros is buying shares of Apple Inc. , in contrast to many hedge funds; in fact, Apple lost its place as the most popular stock among hedge funds last quarter to AIG (AIG) (find more of hedge funds' favorite stocks). The fall in Apple's stock price, in anticipation of an era of lower earnings, has brought the trailing earnings multiple down to 10. Market expectations are diverging wildly from analysts, whose growth expectations currently imply a five-year PEG ratio of 0.5. That is probably too rosy a prediction but it's certainly possible that Apple will manage to keep its net income about flat.

Message.Title: Apple's Unusual, Direct Attack On Samsung And Android Surprises Even The Apple Bloggers
Message.Msg: Last night, Apple executive Phil Schiller went to Reuters, the Wall Street Journal, and Bloomberg to trash Samsung and Android. The reason: Tonight, Samsung reveals its latest flagship phone, the Galaxy S4. Over the past year, Samsung has emerged as a real threat to Apple's ownership of the smartphone market. Schiller gave all three outlets the same quotes. He said Android is a "fragmented" platform where users have to sign-up for nine different services to get their phones working properly. He said that Android's marketshare is only so high because feature-phone owners are getting free upgrades to Android phones. He said that four times more Android users are switching to iPhone than iPhone users are switching to Android. Schiller's move surprised the Apple bloggers. Daring Fireball's Jon Gruber called it "unusual." It’s clearly no coincidence that Schiller granted this interview the day before the Galaxy S4 launch in New York, and it is an unusual thing for Apple to do. (Usually, when they want to deflate attention from a competitor’s announcement, they do it by releasing a minor update to an existing Apple product.) MG Siegler was more negative: I’m not sure which is more strange: 1) That Phil Schiller would say anything the day before a big Samsung event. 2) That Phil Schiller would say anything, period. 3) That Schiller doesn’t mention Samsung, but mentions Android. 4) That WSJ sort of throws him under the bus with their headline (and rightfully so, in this case). It’s so rare for this type of interview; normally you only see one that is heavily teed-up to help Apple in some way. The very lede: “Apple Inc. is on the defensive.” — does not help Apple in any way, shape, or form. Good for WSJ. 5) That this article has two authors — Ian Sherr and Jessica E. Lessin — and it’s less than 300 words. I guess you could argue that Apple is fighting up here, since Android is “winning” the market share battle. But I fail to see how this statement is a smart maneuver. It makes Apple look vulnerable. Weird.

Message.Title: PHIL SCHILLER is a Shill--desperate
Message.Msg: Samsung had 30.3 percent of the smartphone market in 2012, up from 19 percent a year earlier. Apple's share was 19.1 percent last year, up from 18.8 percent in 2011. However, Schiller said he believes the iPhone offers a better experience. 'Android is often given as a free replacement for a feature phone and the experience isn't as good as an iPhone,' he told the Wall Street Journal. He said one of Androids biggest problems was the amount of time it takes to set up. 'When you take an Android device out of the box, you have to sign up to nine accounts with different vendors to get the experience iOS comes with,' he said. 'They don't work seamlessly together.' Schiller told Reuters that Google's own research showed the vast majority of Android users were stuck on older versions of the software, and that Samsung's new phone itself may debut with a year-old operating system that will need updating. 'With their own data, only 16 percent of Android users are on year-old version of the operating system,' he said.

Message.Title: An Observation Of A Few Issues With Apple
Message.Msg: Competitors are simply catching up, and in some cases surpassing Apple. It was just a matter of time. Did people really think every other technology company on the planet was just going to sit there and watch Apple dominate everything? I also think people have become reluctant on getting chained to a specific ecosystem. With Apple, its got to be an Apple everything or it doesn't work, much "unlike" everything else. This may have been a good strategy a few years back as all their products were superior, but today its not holding water. A good example is once Apple updates their Mac OS to a new version, all of a sudden you need to install the new OS or some things no longer work. For example, an 18 month old Mac running Snow Leopard can't all of a sudden access iCloud, you'll need to upgrade to Mountain Lion. Yes, this is fact and turns a lot of people off. The next Apple product to get whacked down will probably be iTunes. In a few years, iTunes will be half of what it is now.

Message.Title: AAPL will rebound BIG on good news
Message.Msg: This board is full of so much nonsense. The p/e is compressed to the 9-10 range and AAPL typically has one of about 13. That means a revenue plateau doesn't justify the price. It's oversold and its not moving down much because no one wants to sell at such an obvious bottom. They have $138 cash per share. Net that out and the share price is less than $200. This is a situation where bad news will have little to no effect and good news will have an exaggerated one. The price will return to the 500-550 range after the earnings are released. I can't believe people are actually shorting at these levels. Anyone doing that must have no brain.

Topic.Title: M.Lee: But Walt margins will be lower

Message.Msg: IMO, it will end when two things happen...rather, when Apple makes two things happen. (1). They execute rapid sales and profit growth in China and India on the back of a new lower cost phone. (2) they successfully execute the launch of a new product category...iTV or iWatch, for instance. Doing these will answer the markets' overblown concerns about shrinking revenue, shrinking margins, and shrinking ability to innovate. And, it may take 12-18 months for Apple to fully answer these concerns.

Topic.Title: If Apple was smart,

Message.Msg: Apple has a great products and services, a company that works to break the limits, to give it's customers the best design and support in the industry. You can't predict a stock price for any company, but you can usually tell when a company is growing and doing well, My view is Apple is a good company, and I would buy both up and down as an investment. However if you are a short term trader, you view will differ, and the company stock may become a moving target. Bottom line stop trying to duck hunt a growth stock

Topic.Title: Cook will ruin Samsung's launch tomight with a press release.

Message.Msg: If you break down the numbers of the 3-year 45 billion plan, roughly 15 billion is dedicated for share buybacks with the remaining 30 billion allocated towards the quarterly dividends. On 2/7/13, the company announced that as of 2/15, they would have spent 10 billion of the original plan established last year. 7.5 billion of that 10 billion went to fund the (3) quarterly dividends, leaving only 1.5 billion used for share buybacks. That of course was as of 2/15/13, so hopefully more funds have been used for share buybacks since that press release on 2/7/13. Additionally, the company stated that they made 23 billion in cash just last quarter and would be returning even more cash to shareholders. That means in addition to the original program announced last March on 3/19/12. I would suspect they'd increase the original 45 billion program to at least 60 billion with much more allocated towards share buybacks this time, with a modest increase to the current dividend. Everyone wants a 1-time special dividend, but I'm hoping the company increases the current dividend because it would pay off more over the long-term and is sustainable with the company's cash flow. Who knows, maybe we get both!

Message.Title: Goldman Sachs Slashes Estimates On Apple Supplier Foxconn
Message.Msg: March 14, 2013 11:24 AM EDT Goldman lowered estimates on another Apple supplier, Foxconn Tech, as they expect the potential plastic casing adoption in future low-cost iPhones (from metal casing for the current iPhone) to have a significant impact on its earnings. The firm cut 2013E/2014E EPS estimates by 12%/7%. "We believe Foxconn Tech is not likely to focus on plastic casing as its edge is on metal casing while plastic casing has low entry barriers," the analyst said. "According to our sensitivity analysis, we expect +2%/-2% earnings variation from our base case in 2013E. Yet we expect the shift is to cater to market demand, which is very price sensitive. Foxconn Tech remains captive to Hon Hai and Apple demand for its metal casing business, which accounts for close to 80% of its 2013E profit, in our view."

Topic.Title: Cook will ruin Samsung's launch tomight with a press release.

Message.Msg: fight back with what? Small screen phones that people don't want except for the "birkenstock" bunch, and they are getting old and dying. I've shown my Note II to probably 10 young people with iphones and nearly had to mug them to get my Note II back. They are doing loads of video and game stuff and it boils down to whether you can see or not. Do you watch a ten inch screen at home or a 55" screen? Both Samsung and Apple make good phones as far as their operation goes, but I actually read books on my Note II. Loads of friends in college are now dumping their iphones for the Note II, because they can use it as both a tablet and phone. I must admit, I don't use my 7" tablet anymore, as the Note II has pretty much taken over. One device covers it all.

Message.Title: Apple’s Already Lost’ to Samsung
Message.Msg: Play Video'Apple's Already Lost' to Samsung: Porter Bibb Thursday, 14 Mar 2013 | 12:38 PM ET Samsung has been taking global market share and will soon top Apple in the United States, venture capitalist Porter Bibb says. Samsung has been taking global market share and will soon top Apple in the United States, venture capitalist Porter Bibb said Thursday. "Apple's already lost," he said. "Samsung has taken over the global market share in terms of smartphones and tablets, and Apple still has a marginal lead here in the U.S., but during the second quarter this year, Samsung will become the market leader here, as well." On CNBC's "Fast Money," Bibb said that Samsung's new Galaxy S4 smartphone would be a driver of market share for the South Korean technology giant.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: The Taiwanese contract manufacturer is the largest foundry, or maker of chips that are designed by other companies. DigiTimes reported that the company is expected to tape out Apple’s next A7 processor in a 20-nanometer manufacturing process in March and then begin volume production in May and June. That could pave the way for commercial shipments in the first quarter of 2014. TSMC declined to comment to DigiTimes. (Note, DigiTimes has had a spotty record on reporting rumors). If true, the move makes sense for Apple, as it is locked in litigation with Samsung, the current supplier of its A series chips. A chip is “taped out” when the circuit design process is completed (such designs used to be put on computer tapes). But it takes a while to stamp the bugs and move into large-scale production. TSMC spends about $9 billion a year on capital expenses and it competes with the likes of Samsung, UMC, and even Intel. Traditionally, Intel just made its own chips, but it has begun a serious effort to become a foundry for other chip designers.

Topic.Title: Chart of the day: The hedge funds' Google vs. Apple trade

Message.Msg: By Michael Shulman, InvestorPlace Contributor | Mar 14, 2013, 9:52 am EDT Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is no longer the darling of Wall Street or of individual investors. A pity, as it is beyond cheap as a stock and beyond excellent as a platform for generating profits if you are an investor looking for appreciation, an income investor or a speculator. Growth Investor You may be annoyed at Tim Cook for not being Steve Jobs, and for Apple commanding only 65% of the tablet market and not 85% by yearend, but if Apple has a bad tear, it should still grow 15%-18% and will probably grow between 20% and 25%. And when Apple grows revenues, it typically grows profits at the same rate. Using the second grade math – some might argue the only math I seem to be capable of – Apple is selling at a two-thirds discount to the S&P 500 based on the next two years of growth, earnings and cash on the balance sheet: Translation: Apple, if priced as other stocks in the S&P 500, is worth roughly $1200-$1240 a share.

Topic.Title: Apple Conference Call - same as last year, it will be coming monday - bet your money on it.

Message.Msg: Last Year, this is how the company announced the 45 Billion 3-year buyback and dividend program. Monday 3/18/12, they announced that a conference call will come Tuesday 3/19/12, pre-marekt. Apple Conference Call WHAT: Tim Cook, Apple’s CEO, and Peter Oppenheimer, Apple’s CFO, will host a conference call to announce the outcome of the Company’s discussions concerning its cash balance. Apple® will not be providing an update on the current quarter nor will any topics be discussed other than cash. WHERE: Via conference call. The dial-in number for press is (877) 616-0063 (toll-free) or (719) 219-0041. Please enter confirmation code 592016. WHEN: Monday, March 19, 2012 at 6:00 a.m. PDT/9:00 a.m. EDT Then on 3/19/12, the actual announcement of the program: Apple Announces Plans to Initiate Dividend and Share Repurchase Program Expects to Spend $45 Billion Over Three Years CUPERTINO, California—March 19, 2012—Apple® today announced plans to initiate a dividend and share repurchase program commencing later this year. Subject to declaration by the Board of Directors, the Company plans to initiate a quarterly dividend of $2.65 per share sometime in the fourth quarter of its fiscal 2012, which begins on July 1, 2012. Additionally, the Company’s Board of Directors has authorized a $10 billion share repurchase program commencing in the Company’s fiscal 2013, which begins on September 30, 2012. The repurchase program is expected to be executed over three years, with the primary objective of neutralizing the impact of dilution from future employee equity grants and employee stock purchase programs. “We have used some of our cash to make great investments in our business through increased research and development, acquisitions, new retail store openings, strategic prepayments and capital expenditures in our supply chain, and building out our infrastructure. You’ll see more of all of these in the future,” said Tim Cook, Apple’s CEO. See that last line - you'll see MORE!!!

That means, they only bought back roughtly 1.5 billion because the rest of the 7.5 billion was used to fund the (3) quarterly dividends! There needs to be more funding allocated towards the buyback! I would hope at least 15-20 billion is dedicated toward the buyback program. Even Buffet stated that Cook needs to ignore the various requests for preferred stock and buy back his own stock at $.80 to the $1.00. It's the best way to increase shareholder value over the long-term!

Message.Title: SAMSUNG ROCKS, HUAWEI RIPS, AND RAMOS DIGITAL KILLS!!!!
Message.Msg: What do all 3 of these companies have in common? They are beating apple with their stronger core of design engineers and speed to market agility. apple is in just the early stages of the large oversized broken core break-down. just like compaq-hewett and dell and research in motion and nokia and, and, and.... Apple is rotting from the inside out, and it's confusing the street and some of the more respected analsts across the globe. one look at apple's chart and you can see money flow and on bal volume is trending lower...and all indicators look horid on apple from a technical stance. i expect small 3 to 14 point counter pops in the stock to lure in bottom feeders and the so-called "value-investor and mutual fund". if you want dead money to losing money and a puny dividend, then apple's your dog. help yourself. however, i warned everyone on this message board last oct and nov that apple was breaking down, and that breakdown continues today. the wiser analysts on the street are finally catching on to apple's deteriorating margins, glut in inventory that coninues to balloon due to the fall off in retail store demand. everyone today wants a samsung, samsung is the new cool, and steve would have said it. god bless steve, rest his soul. i miss him like all of you probably do. if he was still healthy and working at apple, i would still be long the stock. what a difference it makes when a genius leaves and there are simply no shoes to fill his shoes. right?

Topic.Title: Samsung Galaxy S4 will make iPhone look old

Message.Msg: Obsolete yes, old, no. Huge mistake for Samsung to make the S4 look exactly like the S3. Another played out plastic phone, and the screen is bigger so millions of people won't want it. What do you expect, Samsung cant think of anything new unless they're copying it so they have to wait until apple comes out with a new shape to copy it. But apple is gonna make the biggest mistake of their lives if they give Samsung 6 months with the S4 to compete with their now obsolete iPhone 5. The s4 is gonna kill it, they're gonna steal so much market share. And this is precisely why I bought option calls (oct and jan 2014 leaps) this past week. No way Cook can be so stupid and such a coward to not release a 5S at the latest next month. It's possible, production already started and this is why I think they've been cutting back orders for the 5 not because there's no demand. And I really can't believe they didn't release something today to steal some of samsung's thunder. NOTHING. Maybe cook really is a mindless idiot with ZERO imagination and ZERO nerve.

Message.Title: Making way for Apple's iPhone, China Mobile to spend $6.7B building out 4G network
Message.Msg: China Mobile will spend 41.7 billion yuan ($6.7 billion U.S.) to develop 4G technology this year in anticipation of the arrival of the world's most popular smartphone — Apple's iPhone — on the world's most populous wireless carrier. China Mobile revealed on Thursday that it will spend 190.2 billion yuan ($30.1 billion) on its networks this year, with nearly a quarter of that going into its TD-LTE 4G technology, according to Reuters. The next version of Apple's iPhone, according to some industry observers, is expected to support China Mobile's TD-LTE 4G, even though that technology is less widespread in use than FDD-LTE. For China Mobile, the investment will boost speeds on a network that, while hosting 715 million subscribers, lags far behind its competition in connectivity. Only 13 percent of China Mobile subscribers are on 3G, while that figure is 33 percent for China Unicom and 44 percent for China Telecom. China Mobile's 3G speeds are also quite slow, with many users relying on the carrier's widespread Wi-Fi hotspot network for bigger downloads. Despite China Mobile's popularity, the carrier has not yet landed Apple's industry-leading smartphone. More than 10 million of its customers already have iPhones operating on its network, even though the device is not compatible with China Mobile's 3G standard. The inability to offer customers an iPhone on contract, though, is seen as a reason for the carrier's slowing profit growth. China Mobile's 4G network, the company announced at this year's Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, will consist of 200,000 base stations. The network will cover more than 100 Chinese cities and more than 500 million potential users, roughly 37.2 percent of China's population. With more than twice as many subscribers as the United States has citizens, China Mobile represents a massive opportunity for Apple. The iPhone maker has increased its focus on China in recent years, as the world's most populous country recently surpassed the USA.

Message.Title: "Apple investors see upside ahead of Samsung's Galaxy S4 launch"
Message.Msg: "Apple shares gained almost one percent on Thursday, despite this evening's launch of Samsung's new Galaxy S4 smartphone. The S4 is widely rumored to incorporate innovative features that could allow it to take market share from Apple's popular iPhone. Apparently investors feel that either the Galaxy has been over-hyped, or that Apple's stock price already reflects any competitive threat from the S4. Given that Apple will soon announce a plan to return some of it's $140 billion cash hoard to shareholders, today's trading could mark a change in sentiment and a reversal of the 38% slide in share price since late last year." Will post more later

Topic.Title: Why does it seem to always sell off AH

Message.Msg: AH has to be limit orders...... So with little money, bears can hit the bids with small sell orders, and it keeps the bearish "tone" to the stock..... AH is the easiest way to paint the picture on a stock..... Again, these have to be limit orders, so guys can sell small blocks and lower the bid, it doesn't take much and keeps the mood bleak.

Message.Title: CNBC bashing is helping AAPL pricing.
Message.Msg: Their continued focus on shrinking margins and missing the next quarter, has already been discounted into the stock...any beat on margins and numbers will result in a big bump. Based on the projected product mix, Apple should easily beat the margin projections. Add in an acquisition, dividend or buyback and the stock should be in the 525-540 range by late April.

Topic.Title: AAPL will rebound BIG on good news

Message.Msg: Also if you look at Apple's P/E history back more than the last few quarters, you would know that their historical P/E average is closer to 19-21(depending on how you weight the average). The P/E has dramatically compressed over the past 6-8 Quarters. The P/E could very reasonably move to the 15-17 range (that is more inline with history) over the next 3-4 Quarters that would put Apple Trading around $660.00 to $750.00 based on current earnings and $750.00 to $850.00 based on next 12 month expected earnings.

Topic.Title: A question for traders?

Message.Msg: Dude, be careful with the SQQQ. This kind of ultra short ETFs have a natural bearish tendency it isn't the exact opposite of the NAS 100. You can use it to protect short term big drops but it can't protect a slowly degrading market. In order words, if NAS goes down slowly over time, SQQQ will go down as well because of its natural bearish tendency.

So just when your eyes focus on what's down there Android is going to move it upward? Then what, you now have to move your eyes upward to where they started from in the first place? Then what, Android moves the text downward. What is this, a game of Seek and Destroy? Reminds me of those old screen mouse trap malware that as soon as you put the pointer on your object the object moves to a different spot on the screen, and you just keep on chasing it until you get smart and do a Chinese Reset on your computer.

Message.Title: Samsung security
Message.Msg: Samsung Knox — here we go. Samsung showed it off at Mobile World Congress back in Barcelona. It’s a security feature that locks the data on your phone, and separates your data (photos, files, emails, apps, messages) into both a work space and a personal space. This looks and sounds a lot like what we saw on BlackBerry 10. This idea might end up catching on, so don’t be surprised if we see other phone makers introducing similar features later on down the road.

Message.Title: Farther and farther behind
Message.Msg: Apple is still significantly behind the Galaxy 3 ... has not even come close to equalling that phone. Now they are even farther behind. As well as behind LG, Xperia and HTC. Even the Blackberry Z10, with its advanced camera software (perhaps the best on the market) and its innovative shift away from the home button routine, is way ahead of Apple. That is why Apple has tanked for months straight. The iPhone 5 was a flat out embarassment - complete rubbish. And I owned an iPhone 3G for 3 years - yeah , thats right - a 3G - I had an iphone for a long timne before 95% of the people on this board. I switched to Samsung because Apple had become a 2nd tier producer. By the way, the tech boards and blogs are eating the Galaxy 4 up - they love it. The posts here suggesting the Radio City debut was a flop are little more than wishful thinking . Keep dreaming , fanboys. Here's a novel idea - try looking at the product, instead of the name. Message.Title: OLED - An introduction
Message.Msg: A short introduction Developed by major US universities OLED stanbds for organic light emotion diode. It consumes less energy because it doesn't have a back light. OLED is made by an encapsulation process whereby two plastic sheets are filled with layers of various color material. Samsung DID NOT develop the technology and licenses it from UDC (PANL). Samsung and LG are the only companies to master and mass produce such panels (AUO is working hard). Apple does not t manufacturer screens or hardware and is therefore at a disadvantage. It has nothing to do with Tim Cook, Steve Jobs or any other CEO. Apple simply do not have factories. Samsung and LG have both invested close to 2bil dollars in OLED. S$ is just a bridge toward the YOUM flexible and folding OLED screens. I hope that Apple takes the money they have and move to build and manufacturer screens in the US. If they don't apple will be left behind in the coming years.

Message.Title: Apple strategy
Message.Msg: Historically, Apple has always been the underdog. They moved in different directions than the rest. Recently, the pack has caught up and are charging ahead. Now, Apple slows down, letting the competition get farther ahead, then they introduce the next disruptive technology catching them off guard. Brilliant strategy. Its only a matter of time.....
